questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis of the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dermatomyositis

Explanation:

The given image shows a heliotrope rash, which is a characteristic feature of Dermatomyositis.

 

Clinical Features of Dermatomyositis

 

  • Weakness: Symmetric, proximal greater than distal.
  • Rash: Characteristic rashes include:
    • Heliotrope rash: Erythematous eyelid discolouration with periorbital edema.
    • Gottron sign: Erythematous rash over extensor surfaces (knuckles, elbows, knees, ankles).
    • Gottron papules: Raised erythematous rash over knuckles.
    • V-sign: Rash on sun-exposed anterior neck and chest.
    • Shawl sign: Rash over the back of the neck and shoulders.
    • Nail bed telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries at nail beds.
    • Subcutaneous calcium deposits.
  • Weakness and rash can appear together or be separated by months.
  • Some patients may present with only a rash (amyopathic DM), while others may show mainly weakness.
  • Additional Symptoms: Myalgias, arthralgias, dysphagia, and dysarthria.
  • Skin symptoms significantly affect overall life quality; pruritus can be debilitating.
  • Pulmonary Issues: Dyspnea from ventilatory muscle weakness or intrinsic lung problems (interstitial lung disease, bronchopneumonia, alveolitis).
  • Malignancy Risk: Higher risk (~15%) in adult-onset cases within the first 2–3 years.

 

Heliotrope rash

Gottron’s Papules

 

Shawl sign

V Sign

Polymyositis (Option A): Muscle involvement similar to dermatomyositis but lacks skin manifestations.

Inclusion body myositis (Option C):

  • Does not present with a heliotrope rash.
  • The feature distinguishing inclusion body myosistis from dermatomyositis and polymyositis is the lack of responsiveness to immunosuppressive treatment.

Discoid lupus erythematosus (Option D):

  • Carpet track or Tin tack sign, also called Cat's tongue is characteristic of DLE.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient with a known case of ovarian cancer presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, combing hair, etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Dermatomyositis

  • The patient presents with proximal muscle weakness (difficulty in climbing stairs, standing from a chair, and combing hair).

  • The image shows a heliotrope rash or shawl sign, which are characteristic skin findings in dermatomyositis.

  • Dermatomyositis is often paraneoplastic, commonly associated with ovarian cancer.

Dermatomyositis

Feature

Dermatomyositis

Cause

Autoimmune inflammatory myopathy, often paraneoplastic

Muscle Weakness

Symmetrical, proximal muscle weakness

Characteristic Rashes

Heliotrope rash (around eyes)

 

Gottron’s papules

 

Shawl sign

 

V-sign

 

Mechanic’s hand

 

Holster sign

 

Paraneoplastic Association

Ovarian, lung, breast, and gastric cancers

Diagnosis

Elevated CPK, anti-Mi-2, anti-Jo-1, muscle biopsy

Treatment

Corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, cancer screening

Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option A): Incorrect because SLE presents with malar rash, arthritis, and systemic involvement, but not prominent muscle weakness.

Systemic sclerosis (Option C): Incorrect because systemic sclerosis causes skin tightening, Raynaud's phenomenon, and esophageal dysmotility, not proximal muscle weakness.

Cushing syndrome (Option D): Incorrect because Cushing’s causes proximal weakness due to steroid myopathy, but lacks the classic skin rash seen in dermatomyositis.

questions.text: What is the observed condition in the image below, where a 10-year-old boy presents with muscle weakness in his lower limbs and a rash on his eyelids, with biopsy results indicating muscle inflammation?
questions.solution:
• Gottron’s papules are erythematous to violaceous plaques over the extensor surfaces of the knuckles, elbows, and knees.
  • They are characteristic of juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM), an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy.
  • The clinical triad includes proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash (violaceous rash on eyelids), and Gottron’s papules.
  • Muscle biopsy typically shows perivascular and perimysial inflammation with CD4+ T-cell infiltration.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with elevated muscle enzymes (CK, aldolase), electromyography, and MRI findings of myositis.
  • Treatment involves high-dose corticosteroids and immunosuppressants (methotrexate, IVIG).

Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM)

Feature

Description

Definition

Autoimmune inflammatory myopathy affecting muscles and skin in children

Age Group

Common in children aged 5–15 years

Muscle Weakness

Proximal muscle weakness (difficulty climbing stairs, getting up from a chair)

Skin Findings

Gottron’s papules (erythematous plaques over knuckles)

Heliotrope rash (violaceous periorbital rash)

Shawl/V-sign (rash over shoulders and chest)

Lab Findings

↑ CK, aldolase, ANA, anti-Mi-2, anti-Jo-1 antibodies

Diagnostic Tests

Muscle biopsy (perifascicular atrophy, inflammatory infiltrates), MRI, EMG

Treatment

Corticosteroids, methotrexate, IVIG

Mechanic Hands

Holster sign

Shawl sign (Option B) is incorrect because the Shawl sign is a macular erythematous rash over the shoulders, neck, and upper back, typically seen in Dermatomyositis (DM) but does not specifically describe the lesions over the hands.

Heliotrope rash (Option C) is incorrect because a heliotrope rash refers specifically to a purplish rash on the eyelids. While present in JDM, it is not the primary observation being asked in the question.

Scleroderma (Option D) is incorrect because scleroderma presents with skin thickening, tightness, and Raynaud’s phenomenon, not inflammatory myopathy with characteristic rashes like Gottron’s papules.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child visits with symptoms of fever, joint pain, and a visible skin abnormality on his hand, as depicted in the provided image. Please identify the clinical observation and suggest a probable diagnosis.

choices.text:
Sclerodactyly-Systemic sclerosis

Mechanic’s hand – Systemic lupus erythematosus

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Gottron’s papules – Juvenile dermatomyositis

 

Explanation:

  • The image shows erythematous, scaly plaques over the knuckles (MCP and PIP joints), which are characteristic of Gottron’s papules.
  • Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM) is an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy affecting children.
  • Associated features include proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash, and systemic symptoms like fever and arthritis.
  • Diagnosis is based on clinical findings, muscle enzymes (CK), EMG, and muscle biopsy.

Juvenile Dermatomyositis:

Feature

Description

Skin findings

Gottron’s papules (erythematous scaly plaques on knuckles), heliotrope rash (violaceous eyelid discoloration)

Muscle involvement

Proximal muscle weakness (difficulty climbing stairs, combing hair)

Systemic symptoms

Fever, arthritis, fatigue

Investigations

Elevated CK, aldolase, anti-Jo-1 antibodies, EMG, muscle biopsy

Treatment

Corticosteroids, methotrexate, IVIG in severe cases

 

Rheumatoid nodules – Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis (Option B) is incorrect because rheumatoid nodules are firm, non-tender subcutaneous nodules over pressure points (e.g., elbows, fingers) in juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). These nodules are not scaly or violaceous and do not appear over joint extensor surfaces like Gottron’s papules.

 

Sclerodactyly – Systemic sclerosis (Option C) is incorrect because sclerodactyly refers to thickened, tight skin over the fingers due to dermal fibrosis, seen in systemic sclerosis (scleroderma). It is not associated with Gottron’s papules or muscle weakness.

 

Mechanic’s hand – Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option D) is incorrect because mechanic’s hands (hyperkeratotic, cracked palmar skin) are seen in antisynthetase syndrome, often associated with dermatomyositis and polymyositis, but not systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: In a 17-year-old patient, the most distinctive and characteristic indicator of juvenile dermatomyositis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gottron’s papules

Explanation:

  • Gottron’s papules are the most distinctive and characteristic feature of juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM).
  • They appear as violaceous, scaly papules symmetrically distributed over bony prominences, especially the knuckles, elbows, and knees.
  • This is a hallmark finding in both juvenile and adult dermatomyositis and helps distinguish it from other connective tissue diseases.
  • JDM is a rare autoimmune inflammatory myopathy affecting children, characterised by proximal muscle weakness and distinctive skin rashes.

Clinical Features:

  • Muscle involvement:
    • Symmetrical proximal muscle weakness (difficulty climbing stairs, rising from a chair).
    • Gower’s sign may be positive in severe cases.
  • Cutaneous manifestations:
    • Gottron’s papules (violaceous papules over knuckles, elbows, knees).
    • Heliotrope rash (violaceous discolouration around eyelids).
    • Nailfold capillary abnormalities (dilated capillary loops, dropout).
    • Photosensitivity and facial erythema.
  • Systemic involvement:
    • Dysphagia, interstitial lung disease, calcinosis cutis (in chronic cases).

Diagnosis:

  • Raised muscle enzymes: CK, aldolase.
  • MRI (muscle oedema), EMG (myopathic changes).
  • Muscle biopsy: Perifascicular atrophy, inflammatory infiltrates.
  • ANA, anti-Mi-2, anti-MDA5 antibodies (useful in subtypes).

Management:

  • First-line: Corticosteroids (prednisolone) with methotrexate or azathioprine.
  • IVIG, rituximab in refractory cases.
  • Physiotherapy to prevent contractures.

 

Photosensitive skin rash (Option A) is incorrect because while photosensitivity is common in JDM, it is not specific and can be seen in other autoimmune conditions like lupus erythematosus.

Nail bed capillary changes (Option B) is incorrect because abnormal nailfold capillaries (dilated capillary loops, dropout) occur in JDM but are not as distinctive as Gottron’s papules. They are also seen in systemic sclerosis.

Malar rash (Option D) is incorrect because a malar rash is more characteristic of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not JDM. Although JDM can have facial erythema, it does not spare the nasolabial folds, unlike the butterfly rash in lupus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with a history of fever and oral ulcers and has developed erythematous lesions on her face. Comment on the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) SLE

 

Explanation:

 

A 25-year-old female with:

  • Fever

  • Oral ulcers

  • Erythematous facial lesions

These features are classic for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), especially when the facial rash involves the malar (butterfly) region — the cheeks and bridge of the nose — sparing the nasolabial folds.

Feature Description
Demographics Young females (childbearing age)
Fever Common systemic symptom
Oral ulcers Typically painless
Malar rash Butterfly-shaped rash over cheeks and nose
Photosensitivity Rash worsens with sun exposure
Other features Arthritis, serositis, renal involvement, ANA/anti-dsDNA positivity

 

Dermatomyositis (Option B): Presents with heliotrope rash (purple discoloration around eyes), Gottron’s papules, and proximal muscle weakness — not prominent in this case.

 

Melasma (Option C): Brownish hyperpigmented macules over sun-exposed areas, especially face; no fever or oral ulcers.

 

Rosacea (Option D): Facial erythema, telangiectasias, flushing, and pustules; typically in older adults and not associated with systemic symptoms like fever or ulcers.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face. Which among the following is the drug of choice in this condition ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option : B

  • When a patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face, the drug of choice for this condition is Isotretinoin. This condition is known as severe or nodulocystic acne, and Isotretinoin is considered the most effective treatment option for this type of acne.
  • Isotretinoin is a retinoid medication that is derived from vitamin A. It works by reducing the size and activity of the sebaceous glands, which are responsible for producing excess oil that contributes to the development of acne. Isotretinoin also has anti-inflammatory properties, helping to reduce inflammation associated with nodulocystic acne

Incorrect options:

Option A) Steroids: Steroids, such as corticosteroids, are not the first-line treatment for nodulocystic acne. While they can help reduce inflammation, they are not typically used as the primary treatment for this condition. Steroids may be used in certain cases when there is a need to rapidly reduce inflammation, but they are not the preferred long-term treatment option.

Option C) Erythromycin: Erythromycin is an antibiotic that can be used to treat acne, particularly in cases of mild to moderate acne. However, it is not the drug of choice for nodulocystic acne. Erythromycin is more commonly used as part of combination therapy or in cases where there is a bacterial component contributing to acne.

Option D) Tetracycline: Tetracycline is another antibiotic that can be used in the treatment of acne, including moderate to severe forms. However, it is not the drug of choice for nodulocystic acne. Tetracycline and other oral antibiotics may be used as adjunctive therapy in combination with other treatments, but they are not typically relied upon as the sole treatment for nodulocystic acne.
